$\alpha_A , \beta_B, \gamma_C, \delta_D$ are called the principal spinors of $\Psi_{ABCD}$.  The corresponding real null vectors determine the principal null directions of $\Psi_{ABCD}$. The classification of space-times according to the principal null directions of the Weyl tensor is known as Petrov classification~\cite{petrov}. As in the case of electromagnetism if none of the principal null directions coincide the space-time is algebraically general of type I, and if all four principal null directions coincide the space-time is of type N. 
If there are two pairs of repeated principal null directions the space-time is of type D.

\section{Special electromagnetic fields and cosmic censorship}
It turns out that formation of singularities as a  result of gravitational collapse is inevitable in classical general relativity, given some very reasonable assumptions~\cite{singtheo}. The presence of singularities in a space-time leads to violation of causality and asymptotic predictability. To preserve the deterministic nature of physics Penrose proposed the cosmic censorship conjecture (CCC)~\cite{penrose.orig.ccc} which asserts that gravitational collapse of a body always ends up in a black hole surrounded by an event horizon rather than a naked singularity. A singularity hidden behind an event horizon is harmless as opposed to a naked one since distant observers will not receive any effects propagating out of them. This way causality and determinism is preserved in the space-time excluding the black hole region bounded by the event horizon.

It has not been possible to establish a concrete proof of CCC. For that reason Wald constructed an alternative thought procedure to test the stability of event horizons~\cite{wald74}.
